topic.title: HP Helion 1.0 Development Platform: Upgrading Application Lifecycle Service

body.p:
Application Lifecycle Service 1.0 provides the ability to upgrade a node or cluster in place via kato node upgrade
without the need to rebuild the entire cluster. This section covers how the upgrade process works.

section.title: Maintenance Mode
section.p:
Before beginning an upgrade, put Application Lifecycle Service in maintenance mode in the
Cloud Controller Settings or the following kato command:

codeblock.codeph: $ kato config set cloud_controller_ng maintenance_mode true

section.p: This shuts down API requests but continues to serve web requests. The Management Console becomes "read only" with the exception of this toggle so that it can be brought back online. Remember to disable maintenance mode once the upgrade has been completed.

section.title: RSA keys
section.p: For cluster upgrades, you should set up SSH keys for password-less authentication between the Core node and all other cluster nodes. Without this, you will be prompted for the 'helion' system user password multiple times for each node.

section.title: Node upgrade ordering
section.p: When performing a cluster upgrade, the nodes in the cluster are automatically arranged into an upgrade order based on the roles they have enabled. This order is then followed when upgrading nodes.

Nodes are matched to this ordering by the roles they have enabled. Any nodes that don't match (e.g. data service nodes) are added to the end to be upgraded last.

section.title: Node Upgrade Process
section.p: Each node goes through the following process during an upgrade.

Before any upgrade actions are performed, kato node upgrade performs a self-update check to make sure it is running the latest code available. After this base check, the version of Application Lifecycle Service running on the node is checked against the latest version available. If a newer version of Application Lifecycle Service is available (or if the --force option was used) the upgrade process begins.
section.note: Using the --force option is not recommended unless you have been directed to do so by HP Application Lifecycle Service Support.
section.p: A pre-upgrade validation check is performed on the node to check that it is in working order before any upgrade actions are performed. If this validation fails then the upgrade process is stopped. These validation steps can be displayed to the user as errors while still continuing the upgrade process by using the --ignore-inspect-failures option.
section.note: Use this option is only if you get failures running kato node inspect that are known to be caused by systems outside of the control of Application Lifecycle Service, or if directed by HP Application Lifecycle Service Support.
section.p:
Next, the upgrade packages are downloaded and a validation check is performed on the files to make sure everything required for an upgrade is available. If the node is a DEA it is then
retired to make sure any applications running on the node are evacuated before the upgrade takes place.

After the components have been upgraded, the node is restarted and then post-upgrade validation takes place. If any failures occur, the upgrade process is stopped and you will be given the option to roll back the upgrade. As with the pre-upgrade validation, this can be skipped using the --ignore-inspect-failures option (see warning above).
When kato node upgrade completes successfully, the node is restarted running the latest version of Application Lifecycle Service.
Remember to take the node out of maintenance mode after the upgrade.
